cluster_relations.rel_desc: The butterfly egg stage occurs on host plants where eggs are laid.
cluster_relations.object_class_label: Butterfly Life Cycle Organisms and Host Plants

qualifiers.OperationalConstraint: specific host plants suitable as hosts

remarks: Stage-location relation inferred from combination of chunk and entity description.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: The caterpillar attaches its body to a leaf before forming the chrysalis.
The caterpillar may attach its body to a plant stem before forming the chrysalis.
Metamorphosis is described as taking place inside the chrysalis casing.

args.canonical_rel_desc: A biological stage or process takes place in, on, or at a specified physical location or host organism.
args.justification: Both relations describe where a biological stage or process (butterfly egg stage, metamorphosis) takes place relative to a physical host or structure (host plants, chrysalis), differing only in prepositions ('on' vs. 'inside') but sharing the same core predicate semantics of occurrence at a location.

These relations connect biological stages or processes to the locations where they occur (host plant surfaces, chrysalis casing), forming a coherent class of location-focused relations for life stages or processes.
The primary semantics is spatial: specifying where in space (on host plants, inside the chrysalis) the stage or process occurs.

args.canonical_rel_desc: An organism or body part affixes itself to a physical substrate or support structure.
args.justification: Both relations describe the caterpillar physically attaching its body to a plant surface (leaf or stem) as a support before forming the chrysalis; this is a physical attachment to a substrate, not merely co-location.
These edges represent a specific type of physical interaction where one entity (the caterpillar) affixes itself to another (leaf or stem), forming a natural class of physical attachment relations.
The semantics is a concrete physical interaction between organism and substrate (active attachment), going beyond mere spatial co-location.
